awd_titl_txt: Extrinsic neuromodulation is a general mechanism to stabilize neural network function during temperature changes
awd_abstract_narration:
How nerve cells in the brain deal with temperature changes is not well understood. The electrical activity that nerve cells produce rely on a well-balanced flow of ions across the cell membrane. It is this balance that is critically altered by temperature, leading to failures in neural activity and accordingly severe consequences for vitality. Many animals have evolved compensatory mechanisms allowing their brains to function over a wider temperature range. This research elucidates such evolutionary conserved mechanisms with a novel approach by studying the same nerve cells in several different species of crustaceans. Crustaceans are ideal systems to address these issues because of their large and identified nerve cells and they live at a variety of temperatures. Recognizing evolutionarily conserved mechanisms for temperature compensation is not only crucial for understanding how animals survive in continuously changing environments, they are ultimately also a prerequisite for the investigation and treatment of hyper- and hypothermia. This project will provide comprehensive training in identifying temperature effects on nerve cell physiology and in cutting-edge electrophysiology for all levels of students. Results will be disseminated publicly through Youtube and a variety of public outreach programs. 

Possessing compensatory mechanisms that maintain vital neuronal activity when temperature changes is critical for animal survival. Recent data from central pattern generators in the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system have shown that descending projection neurons that provide extrinsic neuromodulation to motor networks can counterbalance detrimental temperature effects in these networks. Compensation is achieved by counterbalancing temperature-dependent increases of ionic conductances, allowing for a quick and flexible response to temperature influences. Descending projection neurons are universal building blocks in the motor circuits of many taxa, and the goal of this project is to test the hypothesis that temperature compensation via neuromodulation is a widespread phenomenon and evolutionarily conserved. Experiments will be carried out on several closely and distantly related crustaceans with various evolutionary backgrounds and temperature tolerances. Specifically, extra- and intracellular recordings, including voltage- and dynamic clamp, from identified modulatory and pattern generating neurons in the stomatogastric ganglion will (1) determine temperature compensation in related species with similar temperature tolerance and (2) determine temperature compensation in distantly related species with different temperature tolerance. This study will show that neuromodulation is more than a means to increase flexibility in the nervous system in that it stabilizes neuronal activity in a functional context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the biggest challenges for neuronal systems is to continue to function when temperature changes. Even changes of only a few degrees during fever can have significant effects on brain performance. In invertebrates, changes in environmental temperatures can have stark consequences for the animal's behavior. Such consequences may be particularly dramatic considering ongoing global warming that exposes invertebrates to more frequent and excessive heatwaves. At the core of these problems for nerve cells is the flow of ions through their membranes that is required for normal neuronal activity and synaptic signaling. Each ion flow increases differently with temperature, which disturbs their well-coordinated interplay and ultimately leads to a failure of nervous system function. If this is the case in a vital neuronal system, this has a fatal outcome.

Intellectual merit.

Much about the nervous system's response to temperature changes remains unknown. Why, for example, can brains in some animal species cope better with temperature changes then others? Possessing compensatory mechanisms that counterbalance detrimental temperature effects and maintain vital behaviors is important for survival and provides potential evolutionary advantages to a species. The goal of this award was to study evolutionary conserved mechanisms of neuronal temperature robustness. We had previously learned that the release of neuronal (neuro-)peptides can provide thermal protection to nerve cells and allow them to continue to function at elevated temperature. In this award, we tested whether this mechanism is evolutionary conserved, i.e., if it has the same protective effect in multiple species. We studied several species of decapod crustaceans (crabs, crayfish) to compare the same neuronal circuit in species that live in various temperature habitats.

One main finding is that the nervous systems of species that live in temperature-variable habitats show the greatest temperature robustness. Generally, the activity of the neuronal pattern generators we studied showed normal activity over a wide temperature range (~20°C). However, in species living in variable temperature conditions, this range was expanded (~30°C) and acclimated slowly over several months when the animal's habitat temperature changed.

Two major, but distinct mechanisms enabled large temperature robustness: A) emergent actions of intrinsic ('within') neuronal circuit properties or B) extrinsic ('outside') modulatory neuropeptide influences. While both mechanisms were present in all neuronal circuits we tested, their contribution varied dramatically between circuits. Nevertheless, in all species and circuits, when modulation was prevented, comparatively small temperature changes terminated neuronal activity. Conversely, increasing modulator actions rescued activity and provided temperature robustness.

We conclude that neuromodulation counterbalances detrimental temperature effects, and that this is a widespread mechanism. While neuromodulation is often thought to increase flexibility in the nervous system, our study shows that it can also stabilize neuronal activity in a functional context.

Broader impacts.

This grant led to the publication of 13 scientific manuscripts on neuronal temperature responses. Societal awareness of our planet's rising temperatures has skyrocketed, given the ever more frequent heat records and severe whether events. Our research has been shared widely on social media, contributing to societal awareness of climate change and to the understanding of how global warming may affect vulnerable animal species that cannot actively regulate their body temperature. Assessing the ability of these animals to adapt to varying temperature conditions holds significant societal and economic implications, given the substantial role of decapod crustaceans in the food industry.

The grant has played a crucial role in training one High school student, seven undergraduates, three graduate students, and two postdoctoral fellows, and allowed them to attend national and international meetings. Three more graduate students benefitted from new research lines established by this grant. 42 presentations (oral and posters) were given. Students received several awards (graduate: best oral presentation, best poster at international meeting; undergraduate: best poster award at regional meeting; two competitive research fellowships). A PhD student funded by this grant was awarded best doctoral thesis and best PhD student teaching at Illinois State University. The PhD student now pursues a career in academia. A former postdoctoral fellow now leads their own laboratory studying global warming-related host finding in ticks.

The principal investigator has presented the research funded by this grant at several invited seminars, including a widely televised seminar at the Alfried Krupp Institute for Advanced Study in Germany. At Illinois State University, the lab hosted several outreach activities, including visits by local High schoolers, stakeholders, and virtual lab tours to students from other universities during the Covid pandemic. The principal investigator serves as a judge for the Illinois State High school research symposium and is an academic mentor to several junior faculty members.  

Professionally, the lab organizes the Neuroethology and Invertebrate Neuroscience social at the Society for Neuroscience meeting with more than 100 participants and the lab research questions and approaches are disseminated on the lab YouTube channel. Several of these videos are aimed at undergraduate students and the public.
